renzocastro:
Para ejecutar las funciones quizás puedas usar:
`options.click.apply(this, arguments);`

Por el momento yo estoy usando:

``` javascript
this['details'] = details;
...
options.click.apply(this, [this]);
```
. `this` no hace referencia al mapa, hace referencia al contexto de la función que en este caso sería el mismo marker.

. There are a list of tips here that handle this situation: https://github.com/HPNeo/gmaps/wiki/Tips
. You could add une using some of the custom controls: 

``` javascript
    map.addControl({
      position: 'top_right',
      text: 'Print',
      style: {
        margin: '5px',
        padding: '1px 6px',
        border: 'solid 1px #717B87',
        background: '#fff'
      },
      events: {
        click: function(){
          window.print(); // Be aware some browsers would have another ways to launch this
        }
      }
    });
```
. I'm not sure you can accomplish this with plain JS. I'd probably add some button that creates a StaticMapURL and open as a new window where the user can print it. Or link it to another page that loads that url and has the "window.print()" button. 
. Pull Requests for this are welcomed :)

I think given that it should take the same path format as a polyline, if a relative format is desired as an alternative then that should be defined for polyline and polygon at the same time.  For my purposes I prefer absolute values, so I can just measure the exact latitude and longitude.
. Array of arrays is much shorter and easier to read.  It can also be directly serialized/deserialized to JSON.  It's one of the key benefits of this library.

Kerrick:
It's not a copyright issue, it's a service availability issue. Google is well within their rights to revoke API access to any developer caught using gmaps to access the Google Maps API.

That said, the likelihood of them doing so is slim to none. It's still an issue to be aware of.

qiao:
Github does not set the correct content-type header for the link.

```
>> curl -I https://raw.github.com/HPNeo/gmaps/master/gmaps.js   
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.0.13
Date: Thu, 07 Jun 2012 16:52:56 GMT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
Connection: keep-alive
Status: 200 OK
X-RateLimit-Limit: 100
X-Frame-Options: deny
X-RateLimit-Remaining: 100
X-Runtime: 25
Content-Length: 1
Cache-Control: no-cache
```

The content-type is set to be `text/plain` instead of `text/javascript`. And IE will not execute the script due to the mismatch.

Also, serving scripts from code repositories is not a good idea.
You may refer to [this post](http://zoompf.com/blog/2012/05/html5shiv-and-serving-content-from-code-repositories) for more details.
. @mwmwmw see http://zoompf.com/blog/2012/05/html5shiv-and-serving-content-from-code-repositories

tl;dr
1. uncompressed
2. uncached
3. unstable

walterdavis:
I generally use Prototype for everything, don't really like jQuery at all. I know I could do the noConflict() thing, but I still don't like the idea of loading two monolithic frameworks. I'm interested in Zepto, but I don't like the idea of only supporting modern browsers. One of the reasons I've standardized on Prototype is for its leveling effect across a wide range of browsers. One API to rule them all!

Walter

phillipsj:
Listening to the resize event, and reseting the center of the map should fix the issue that you are experiencing as the center is no updated on resize.

So something like this in the event:

```
var center = map.getCenter();
map.setCenter(center);
```
. Any time the div that holds the map is changed a refresh will need to be called.
. I will verify if this works as I expect it to and I can add that to the gmaps refresh method if you like.

The markers are in an array: `map.markers`. So if you want to trigger a click on a marker you need to know the position of the marker in the array. Then you can do `google.maps.event.trigger(map.markers[your-position-number-here],'click');`

More accurate solution:
- Go to Google Cloud Plateform (Google API console),
- "API & Services" on the left menu,
- "Library" on the left Menu,
- In "Google Maps APIs" section, choose "Google Maps JavaScript API",
- And, very intuitive again, click "Enable" at the top of this page https://i.imgur.com/YcmMZ5G.png

That worked (the grunt jasmine task has an option for this) but it insists on using its own copy of jasmine which it puts in a different directory. . Awesome, cheers mate. 

Now that's landed, I've got a few more ideas if you don't mind me contributing? (if you're wondering, this library helped me immensely a little while ago and I'd like to pay back where I can)
. Oh sweet, I'll see which of those can be translated into jshint configuration. That'll be a pull request for a different day though :)
. Sweet. I'll get on it with these options.

I'm also going to add in camelcase if you don't object? It's covered in the coding standards. 
. I've been pushing on with this this evening. Most of the items above have been quite easily achievable, but a few have been more troublesome. Here's the configuration I've been working with so far

``` json
{

  "camelcase" : false,
  "curly" : true,
  "eqeqeq" : true,
  "newcap" : true,

  "shadow" : true,
  "sub" : true,
  "loopfunc" : true,
  "boss" : true
}
```

You'll notice that I'm not using `camelcase`, `indent` or `strict` as they all had greater reach than I envisaged, and I wanted to check with your before pushing on with them. 

`camelcase` extends its reach to variable names as well as functions. The variable names all seem to be in `snake_case` and I didn't want to just change them. What are you thoughts on this?

`indent` seems is very strict about indentation and would require a fair bit of reformatting. I'm happy to do this, but again just wanted to check with you first.

`strict` would require that we put `"use strict"` directives in every function, or refactor the code a little so that everything is in a self-executing function (the `"use strict"` statements cascades to inner functions).

The last four options (relaxing options) I had to add to get compliance without going above and beyond what we initially discussed. Most of them are pretty sane, but some things would require a more intimate knowledge of the codebase to know if they're safe to change. e.g. excluding `boss` in the above config would have jshint complain about using assignments in cases where comparisons are expected - which makes sense. But there's at least one example of that in the codebase, and I didn't know if it was safe to change or if it relied on some truthy-ness of JS. It'd be great if you could clone my branch [jshint-compliance](https://github.com/WickyNilliams/gmaps/tree/jshint-compliance), disable each in turn and see what you think.

Cheers

yagoferrer:
Ok. I found out how to do this. I'll be adding an example soon.
. When you createMarker() save the reference into an Array:

``` js
var groupA = {};
var newMarker = Map.createMarker(options);
// Add the newMarker to the Map here...
groupA[{uniqueId}] = newMarker;
```

Now all you have to do is to for/loop the Array and use the setVisible() method to change the visibility. 

``` js
for (var i in groupA) {
groupA[i].setVisible(false); // true/false
}
```

If you have assigned a uniqueId, then you can change visibility of a single marker:

``` js
groupA[{uniqueId}].setVisible(false); // true/false
```

You can change any marker properties and they will get reflected on the map. That works pretty good.

kevin-brown:
This appears to have been fixed a few months ago, so I think this can be closed off.
. cdnjs now allows for auto-updating in [their package.json for gmaps.js](https://github.com/cdnjs/cdnjs/blob/master/ajax/libs/gmaps.js/package.json), you just need to add a pull request that adds the `autoupdate` key with your configuration. [Here is the one we use with Select2.](https://github.com/cdnjs/cdnjs/blob/38e17355e6e03ab54b9f63dfedb13061066608f0/ajax/libs/select2/package.json#L27-L35)

This should work for an autoupdate configuration for gmaps:

``` json
"autoupdate": {
  "source": "git",
  "target": "git@github.com:hpneo/gmaps.git",
  "basePath": "",
  "files": [
    "*.js",
  ]
},
```
. cdnjs now has the newer versions, but the [version field is still set to 0.4.12](https://github.com/cdnjs/cdnjs/blob/31eee715a9ffa7a6e739da45b7083c0b0dcbc266/ajax/libs/gmaps.js/package.json#L4) in your `package.json`, so the default is still 0.4.12.

This should fix itself during the next gmaps release, so this can probably be closed off.

. You can't use a local version of google maps api script. You can cache the loader script for a few minutes if you care to build a proxy, but it won't work for long. Endpoints keep changing, and parts of the internal requests you make to google carry data that is unique for your session.

What's wrong with using google's provided url? 
. I agree in that using

```
instance.parameter = options.parameter || true;
```

is wrong, because if you explicitly set options.parameter to `false`, instance.parameter will still be true.

However, it doesn't sound like a great idea to declare `valueOrDefault` as a global variable. You could as well declare `valueOrDefault` inside GMaps constructor.
. The example you linked is manually instancing markers and infowindows. In gmaps, as @Bin4ry1337 said, adding a marker is a method of the map instance, and adding an infowindow is just an option when doing so.

If you declare 

``` js
    map.addMarker({
        lat: 63.998847,
        lng: 11.486882,
        title: 'Test',
        infoWindow:
        {
            content: 'Hello World'
        }
    });
```

It implicitly instances a marker, which [is appended to `map.markers`](https://github.com/hpneo/gmaps/blob/master/lib/gmaps.markers.js#L126), and which implicitly contains an infowindow instance, which is referenced on its `infoWindow` property.

Therefore, calling

``` js
var markerInstance = map.markers[0];
markerInstance.infoWindow.open(map, markerInstance);
```

will open the infowindow.

To attach a click listener to the DOM element you can use google maps domListener, jQuery listeners or attach onclick events like in your example.

jeffconklin:
Anytime you are requesting a secure URL (https), loading non-https content
will pretty much eliminate the "security"/privacy that you are looking for.
Meaning, when you load https://...anything, all the URLs within your page
need to also be using the https protocol or modern browsers will just block
the 'bad"/insecure content, like you are seeing.

To address this, you can swap out http://maps.google.... for
https://maps.google.com/maps/api/js?sensor=true

You may want to check out this information within their docs...

https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/javascript/tutorial#https-or-http

Hope this helps.

Jeff Conklin
jeffconk@gmail.com
(609) 439-3038
http://jeffconklin.com

> loaded over HTTPS, but requested an insecure script '
> http://maps.google.com/maps/api/js?sensor=true'. This request has been
> blocked; the content must be served over HTTPS."
> 
> I imagine this is a known issue, but I couldn't find any mention of it in
> the documentation. Is there a workaround?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/hpneo/gmaps/issues/442.
. It looks like you are loading the map on the second tab on your page. Since
this is hidden when the page loads, the map element does not have a height
or width (because it is not "there"). So the map is loaded, and google has
returned the tiles back to the no height/width map... which makes it look
empty. Though I don't have a specific solution, you can most likely find
the answer is you search for "Loading google maps on a hidden div". I
believe the fix here might be to initialize or "pretend" that the browser
has resized when the map finally becomes visible. You can either initiate
the map when someone actually clicks the location tab, or perform a resize
call on google maps specifically after the tab is displayed.

Jeff Conklin
jeffconk@gmail.com
(609) 439-3038

> It looks like you are loading the map on the second tab on your page. Since
> this is hidden when the page loads, the map element does not have a height
> or width (because it is not "there"). So the map is loaded, and google has
> returned the tiles back to the no height/width map... which makes it look
> empty. Though I don't have a specific solution, you can most likely find
> the answer is you search for "Loading google maps on a hidden div". I
> believe the fix here might be to initialize or "pretend" that the browser
> has resized when the map finally becomes visible. You can either initiate
> the map when someone actually clicks the location tab, or perform a resize
> call on google maps specifically after the tab is displayed.

SylvainMarty:
Hi !

After the last Chrome update, the methods `getCurrentPosition()` and `watchPosition()` aren't more allowed from a non-ssl adress.

There is only two way to solve that :
- Install a ssl certificate
- Switch to an other Map API

This two methods come from to the browers, not from the Google Maps API.

Thanks for your answer !
